title: Camping moves upmarket, at the risk of losing its soul
summary: In France, the decline in the number of pitches for tents and caravans in favor of mobile homes is worrying some advocates of cheap, open-air vacations.

title: Moody's and Fitch keep France's ratings unchanged
summary: Fitch, which downgraded France's credit rating last year, left it at AA− on Friday evening. Moody's maintained the rating at Aa2, one notch above Fitch.

title: China's auto industry cradle aims to reinvent itself around EVs
summary: In the 1990s and 2000s, French automakers had a strong presence in Wuhan. In recent years, they have been joined by the many Chinese brands now involved in the rapid electrification of the sector.

title: Greece hands Olympic flame to 2024 Paris Games hosts
summary: The Paris Olympics flame was formally handed to French organizers in the all-marble stadium where the first modern Games were held in Athens in 1896.

title: Climate change and the environment take a back seat in Emmanuel Macron's speech on Europe
summary: On Thursday, the French president integrated climate concerns with other challenges, including energy, competitiveness, and production.

title: Near Paris, a pediatric clinic treats young children for 'excessive' screen use
summary: Concerned parents come to pediatrician Sylvie Dieu Osika for help, such as when an child doesn't speak or look people in the eye. When her practice was launched in 2019, the target age was before 11. Now, it has dropped to below 3.

title: In Lebanon, a wave of hostility against Syrian refugees
summary: Dozens of calls for deportation were issued in the country after the murder of a Christian political leader, blamed by the army on a 'Syrian gang.'

title: In Venezuela, Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia, the unknown challenger to Nicolas Maduro
summary: The former diplomat is replacing Maria Corina Machado, who won the primaries of the main opposition coalition but was banned from running for office for one year. He will face the incumbent president on July 28.

title: Tennessee governor signs bill allowing teachers to be armed, a year after Nashville shooting
summary: According to the statute, which becomes effective immediately, parents and other teachers will be barred from knowing who is armed at their schools.

title: Lunch in Paris? 15 (delicious) set menus from 20 to 30 euros
summary: Smoked eel tacos or veggie mezze, fantastic pizzas or Korean dishes: Le Monde picked 15 places in Paris to enjoy a seasonal menu without breaking the bank.

title: Germany's far-right AfD party is mired in scandal
summary: After a series of electoral successes in 2023, the party has faced a series of major scandals. Most recently, its top candidate in the European elections is under judicial investigation for his ties to China and Russia.

title: Paris 2024: All the details on the opening ceremony's security perimeters
summary: Paris police presented the traffic bans, restricted areas, and other measures that will be put in place starting on July 18. Two security perimeters will be set up around the Seine river.

title: France's influence on the European political scene is waning
summary: After playing a leading role in the EU's handling of the Covid-19 crisis and the war in Ukraine, Paris is now increasingly isolated within the EU.

title: EU toughens rules for online fast fashion retailer Shein
summary: Shein, a Chinese-founded fashion platform that has been the target of allegations of environmental and human exploitation, joined a list of large platforms that the EU's Digital Services Act subjects to stricter safety rules.

title: Laurent Cantet, humanist filmmaker who subtly wove social issues and romantic stakes
summary: Winner of the Palme d'Or at Cannes in 2008 with 'The Class,' the director also distinguished himself by turning the corporate world into a cinematic stage with 'Human Resources' in 2000. He died on Thursday, April 25, at the age of 63.

title: Mayors worry their police officers will be 'sucked into' Olympics security arrangements
summary: To reassure mayors, especially those in tourist areas worried about the massive influx of Parisians fleeing the Olympic Games this summer, the Interior Ministry has said neither police nor gendarmes will be allowed to take time off.

title: France and Germany sign deal to co-develop 'tank of the future'
summary: The French and German defense ministers agreed to jointly develop a new battle tank platform with cutting-edge AI and laser weapons technology.

title: Winner chosen in annual Paris baguette 'Grand Prix'
summary: Xavier Netry becomes 31st winner of the competition, meaning his bakery will be a supplier for the Elysée Palace over the next year.

title: Sciences Po students end Gaza war protests after street fight in Paris
summary: University authorities agreed to drop all disciplinary proceedings against demonstrators.

title: In Burkina Faso, 'soldiers wanted to make sure there were no survivors'
summary: According to Human Rights Watch, over 200 civilians were killed at the end of February in the north of the country. It was another massacre blamed on an army unable to contain the jihadist insurgency.

title: In Canada, British Columbia will make changes to its drug decriminalization policy
summary: The province is asking the federal government to make illicit drug use illegal in all public spaces, including inside hospitals, on transit, and in parks.

title: Britain's King Charles will resume public duties next week after cancer treatment
summary: Buckingham Palace say the king will make his inaugural outing following his own cancer diagnosis three months ago to visit a cancer treatment center on Tuesday.

title: UNRWA wins back support from some donor countries following independent review
summary: Germany, one of the main donors to the UN agency in charge of Palestinian refugees, has announced the resumption of its payments. Others may follow. These funds were frozen at the end of January after Israel accused the organization of being infiltrated by Hamas.

title: Six Nations: France in 'final' against England, the kingdom of women's rugby
summary: Facing France on the final day of the competition on Saturday, England's Red Roses are riding the wave of excellent results thanks to a strong championship and the professionalization of their players.

title: Influential Iraqi cleric Moqtada Sadr backs US campus protests for Gaza
summary: As the death toll mounts in Gaza, protesters at universities across the country are demanding schools cut financial ties to Israel.

title: The 'boy mom,' the mother who cannot cut the cord with her son
summary: Anne Chirol reports on the digital archetypes of our time, from the #tradwife to the #fuckboy. This week, the mother who wants to be eternally connected with her son, to whom she is devoted.

title: At the US Supreme Court, debates over Trump's immunity push back the prospect of a trial
summary: On Thursday, the justices considered the former president's request for full immunity. By seeking to define the scope of any partial immunity, they are paving the way for further appeals that could last beyond the presidential election.

title: Chinese electric cars: An existential danger for European automakers
summary: In China, new players from the world of electronics benefit from a complete industry, from ore refining to the factory. But past experience shows that European manufacturers have the capacity to adapt, writes columnist Philippe Escande.
